docs.lead_paragraph: A growing number of beauty brands are introducing hope in a pill, a water bottle or even a candy bar.

headline.main: Nutri-Cosmetics: Eat, Drink and Be Skeptical
headline.print_headline: Nutri-Cosmetics: Eat, Drink and Be Skeptical

docs.snippet: A growing number of beauty brands are introducing hope in a pill, a water bottle or even a candy bar.

docs.lead_paragraph: SCOTT-VINCENT BORBA, an entrepreneur in Woodland Hills, Calif., makes elixirs called Borba Skin Balance Water that hold all the allure of the fountain of youth. Shelved in refrigerators at Sephora stores under signs marked ''Drinkable Skincare,'' the plastic bottles contain mixtures of vitamins and plant extracts that promise to enhance the skin. The label on the ''replenishing'' water, for example, says it has been ''scientifically proven to improve moisture levels by an average of 66 percent,'' while the ''firming'' water advertises itself as ''scientifically proven to improve elasticity by an average of 24 percent.''

headline.main: Skin Deep; Nutri-Cosmetics: Eat, Drink and Be Skeptical

docs.abstract: Growing number of cosmetic companies offer pills, water or candy bars advertised to improve skin, nails and hair; marketers refer to category as 'internal beauty' or 'nutri-cosmetics,' but critics say there is little scientific proof of efficacy of products; photo; drawings (M)

byline.original: By ANTHONY DePALMA and BRUCE LAMBERT

docs.lead_paragraph: THE report issued last month by the Commission on Health Care Facilities for the 21st Century proposes widespread changes in New York State's hospital industry, including the effective elimination of nearly 20 hospitals and the downsizing of dozens more. The recommendations, which in many cases are aimed at specific numbers and types of beds, are based on the premise that the state has too many hospitals and too many beds. The report repeatedly cites this ''excess capacity'' as wasteful, inefficient and costly, and asserts that eliminating it will result in better health care.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Columbia Business School Prof Linda Green questions reasoning of Commission on Health Care Facilities for the 21st Century in proposing elimination of nearly 20 hositals and downsizing of dozens more; holds analysis failed to account for impact of high occupancy levels on emergency room crowding and ambulance diversions (M)
